About UVM Health Network
The University of Vermont Health Network

COVID-19, Flu and RSV:
What to know about this year’s vaccines.
What to know about this year’s vaccines.
For this fall and winter, you can get vaccines to guard against three major respiratory diseases: COVID-19, Flu and RSV.
Getting the vaccine is the best way to reduce the severity and duration of illness caused by these viruses, helping to protect yourself and loved ones.
Contact your primary care provider or local pharmacy to schedule your appointment.
You can also find a vaccine clinic near you by visiting Vaccines.gov.
• Pregnant people - who are 32-36 weeks pregnant during RSV Season.
Talk to your primary care provider to see if the RSV vaccine is right for you or your child.
12 questions answered by our infectious disease experts.

Dr. Cindy Noyes from the University of Vermont Medical Center and Dr. Jessie Leyse from UVM Health Network - Central Vermont Medical Center help answer common questions about the 2023-2024 vaccines and respiratory illnesses.

Cindy Noyes, MD 
Infectious Disease Specialist
UVM Medical Center

Jessie Leyse, MD, MPH
Infectious Disease Specialist
UVM Health Network -
Central Vermont Medical Center

COVID-19, Flu and RSV:
What to know about this year’s vaccines.
What to know about this year’s vaccines.
For this fall and winter, you can get vaccines to guard against three major respiratory diseases: COVID-19, Flu and RSV.
Getting the vaccine is the best way to reduce the severity and duration of illness caused by these viruses, helping to protect yourself and loved ones.
Contact your primary care provider or local pharmacy to schedule your appointment.
Contact your primary care provider or local pharmacy to schedule your appointment.
You can also find a vaccine clinic near you by visiting Vaccines.gov.

• Anyone 60 years and older.
  • Pregnant people - who are 32-36 weeks pregnant during RSV Season.
  • Infants and young children.
• Pregnant people - who are 32-36 weeks pregnant during RSV Season.
Talk to your primary care provider to see if the RSV vaccine is right for you or your child.
